00047 #define KBLOCK  256                     /* Kill buffer block size       */

00060 /*
00061  * Some of the functions in this section are internal, and some are
00062  * actually attached to user keys. Like everyone else, they set hints
00063  * for the display system.
00064  */

00066 /*
00067  * Attach a buffer to a window. The
00068  * values of dot and mark come from the buffer
00069  * if the use count is 0. Otherwise, they come
00070  * from some other window.
00071  */
00072 #if WIN_BTC
00073 #pragma argsused
00074 #endif
00075 globle int usebuffer(
00076   void *theEnv,
00077   int f,
00078   int n)
00079 {
00080         register BUFFER *bp;
00081         register WINDOW *wp;
00082         register int    s;
00083         char            bufn[NBUFN];
00084         char            prompt[NBUFN + 15];
00085 
00086         gensprintf(prompt,"Use buffer [%s]: ",lastbufn);
00087         if ((s=mlreply(theEnv,prompt, bufn, NBUFN)) != TRUE) {
00088                 if (( s == FALSE) && (strlen(lastbufn) != 0))
00089                    genstrcpy(bufn, lastbufn);
00090                 else
00091                    return (s);
00092                 }
00093         if ((bp=bfind(theEnv,bufn, TRUE, 0)) == NULL)
00094                 return (FALSE);
00095         genstrcpy(lastbufn, curbp->b_bname);       /* Save current bufname */
00096         if (--curbp->b_nwnd == 0) {             /* Last use.            */
00097                 curbp->b_dotp  = curwp->w_dotp;
00098                 curbp->b_doto  = curwp->w_doto;
00099                 curbp->b_markp = curwp->w_markp;
00100                 curbp->b_marko = curwp->w_marko;
00101         }
00102         curbp = bp;                             /* Switch.              */
00103         curwp->w_bufp  = bp;
00104         curwp->w_linep = bp->b_linep;           /* For macros, ignored. */
00105         curwp->w_flag |= WFMODE|WFFORCE|WFHARD; /* Quite nasty.         */
00106         if (bp->b_nwnd++ == 0) {                /* First use.           */
00107                 curwp->w_dotp  = bp->b_dotp;
00108                 curwp->w_doto  = bp->b_doto;
00109                 curwp->w_markp = bp->b_markp;
00110                 curwp->w_marko = bp->b_marko;
00111                 return (TRUE);
00112         }
00113         wp = wheadp;                            /* Look for old.        */
00114         while (wp != NULL) {
00115                 if (wp!=curwp && wp->w_bufp==bp) {
00116                         curwp->w_dotp  = wp->w_dotp;
00117                         curwp->w_doto  = wp->w_doto;
00118                         curwp->w_markp = wp->w_markp;
00119                         curwp->w_marko = wp->w_marko;
00120                         break;
00121                 }
00122                 wp = wp->w_wndp;
00123         }
00124         return (TRUE);
00125 }
00126 
00127 /*
00128  * Dispose of a buffer, by name.
00129  * Ask for the name. Look it up (don't get too
00130  * upset if it isn't there at all!). Get quite upset
00131  * if the buffer is being displayed. Clear the buffer (ask
00132  * if the buffer has been changed). Then free the header
00133  * line and the buffer header. Bound to "C-X K".
00134  */
00135 #if WIN_BTC
00136 #pragma argsused
00137 #endif
00138 globle int killbuffer(
00139   void *theEnv,
00140   int f,
00141   int n)
00142 {
00143         register BUFFER *bp;
00144         register BUFFER *bp1;
00145         register BUFFER *bp2;
00146         register int    s;
00147         char            bufn[NBUFN];
00148 
00149         if ((s=mlreply(theEnv,"Kill buffer: ", bufn, NBUFN)) != TRUE)
00150                 return (s);
00151         if ((bp=bfind(theEnv,bufn, FALSE, 0)) == NULL) /* Easy if unknown.     */
00152                 return (TRUE);
00153         if (bp->b_nwnd != 0) {                  /* Error if on screen.  */
00154                 mlwrite("Buffer is being displayed");
00155                 return (FALSE);
00156         }
00157         if ((s=bclear(theEnv,bp)) != TRUE)             /* Blow text away.      */
00158                 return (s);
00159         genfree(theEnv,(void *) bp->b_linep,(unsigned) (sizeof(LINE) + bp->b_linep->l_size));
00160         bp1 = NULL;                             /* Find the header.     */
00161         bp2 = bheadp;
00162         while (bp2 != bp) {
00163                 bp1 = bp2;
00164                 bp2 = bp2->b_bufp;
00165         }
00166         bp2 = bp2->b_bufp;                      /* Next one in chain.   */
00167         if (bp1 == NULL)                        /* Unlink it.           */
00168                 bheadp = bp2;
00169         else
00170                 bp1->b_bufp = bp2;
00171         genfree(theEnv,(void *) bp, (unsigned) sizeof(BUFFER));   /* Release buffer block */
00172         mlwrite("Buffer Killed!");
00173         return (TRUE);
00174 }
00175 
00176 /*
00177  * List all of the active
00178  * buffers. First update the special
00179  * buffer that holds the list. Next make
00180  * sure at least 1 window is displaying the
00181  * buffer list, splitting the screen if this
00182  * is what it takes. Lastly, repaint all of
00183  * the windows that are displaying the
00184  * list. Bound to "C-X C-B".
00185  */
00186 #if WIN_BTC
00187 #pragma argsused
00188 #endif
00189 globle int listbuffers(
00190   void *theEnv,
00191   int f,
00192   int n)
00193 {
00194         register WINDOW *wp;
00195         register BUFFER *bp;
00196         register int    s;
00197 
00198         if ((s=makelist(theEnv)) != TRUE)
00199                 return (s);
00200         if (blistp->b_nwnd == 0) {              /* Not on screen yet.   */
00201                 if ((wp=wpopup(theEnv)) == NULL)
00202                         return (FALSE);
00203                 bp = wp->w_bufp;
00204                 if (--bp->b_nwnd == 0) {
00205                         bp->b_dotp  = wp->w_dotp;
00206                         bp->b_doto  = wp->w_doto;
00207                         bp->b_markp = wp->w_markp;
00208                         bp->b_marko = wp->w_marko;
00209                 }
00210                 wp->w_bufp  = blistp;
00211                 ++blistp->b_nwnd;
00212         }
00213         wp = wheadp;
00214         while (wp != NULL) {
00215                 if (wp->w_bufp == blistp) {
00216                         wp->w_linep = lforw(blistp->b_linep);
00217                         wp->w_dotp  = lforw(blistp->b_linep);
00218                         wp->w_doto  = 0;
00219                         wp->w_markp = NULL;
00220                         wp->w_marko = 0;
00221                         wp->w_flag |= WFMODE|WFHARD;
00222                 }
00223                 wp = wp->w_wndp;
00224         }
00225         return (TRUE);
00226 }
00227 
00228 /*
00229  * This routine rebuilds the
00230  * text in the special secret buffer
00231  * that holds the buffer list. It is called
00232  * by the list buffers command. Return TRUE
00233  * if everything works. Return FALSE if there
00234  * is an error (if there is no memory).
00235  */
00236 globle int makelist(
00237   void *theEnv)
00238 {
00239         register char   *cp1;
00240         register char   *cp2;
00241         register int    c;
00242         register BUFFER *bp;
00243         register LINE   *lp;
00244         register int    nbytes;
00245         register int    s;
00246         char            b[6+1];
00247         char            line[128];
00248 
00249         blistp->b_flag &= ~BFCHG;               /* Don't complain!      */
00250         if ((s=bclear(theEnv,blistp)) != TRUE)         /* Blow old text away   */
00251                 return (s);
00252         genstrcpy(blistp->b_fname, "");
00253         if (addline(theEnv,blistp,"C   Size Buffer           File") == FALSE
00254         ||  addline(theEnv,blistp,"-   ---- ------           ----") == FALSE)
00255                 return (FALSE);
00256         bp = bheadp;                            /* For all buffers      */
00257         while (bp != NULL) {
00258                 if ((bp->b_flag&BFTEMP) != 0) { /* Skip magic ones.     */
00259                         bp = bp->b_bufp;
00260                         continue;
00261                 }
00262                 cp1 = &line[0];                 /* Start at left edge   */
00263                 if ((bp->b_flag&BFCHG) != 0)    /* "*" if changed       */
00264                         *cp1++ = '*';
00265                 else
00266                         *cp1++ = ' ';
00267                 *cp1++ = ' ';                   /* Gap.                 */
00268                 nbytes = 0;                     /* Count bytes in buf.  */
00269                 lp = lforw(bp->b_linep);
00270                 while (lp != bp->b_linep) {
00271                         nbytes += llength(lp)+1;
00272                         lp = lforw(lp);
00273                 }
00274                 int_to_ascii(b, 6, nbytes);             /* 6 digit buffer size. */
00275                 cp2 = &b[0];
00276                 while ((c = *cp2++) != 0)
00277                         *cp1++ = (char) c;
00278                 *cp1++ = ' ';                   /* Gap.                 */
00279                 cp2 = &bp->b_bname[0];          /* Buffer name          */
00280                 while ((c = *cp2++) != 0)
00281                         *cp1++ = (char) c;
00282                 cp2 = &bp->b_fname[0];          /* File name            */
00283                 if (*cp2 != 0) {
00284                         while (cp1 < &line[1+1+6+1+NBUFN+1])
00285                                 *cp1++ = ' ';
00286                         while ((c = *cp2++) != 0) {
00287                                 if (cp1 < &line[128-1])
00288                                         *cp1++ = (char) c;
00289                         }
00290                 }
00291                 *cp1 = 0;                       /* Add to the buffer.   */
00292                 if (addline(theEnv,blistp,line) == FALSE)
00293                         return (FALSE);
00294                 bp = bp->b_bufp;
00295         }
00296         return (TRUE);                          /* All done             */
00297 }
00298 
00299 /*
00300  * The argument "text" points to
00301  * a string. Append this line to the
00302  * buffer. Handcraft the EOL
00303  * on the end. Return TRUE if it worked and
00304  * FALSE if you ran out of room.
00305  */
00306 globle int addline(
00307   void *theEnv,
00308   BUFFER *bufferp,
00309   char    *text)
00310 {
00311         register LINE   *lp;
00312         register int    i;
00313         register int    ntext;
00314 
00315         ntext = strlen(text);
00316         if ((lp=lalloc(theEnv,ntext)) == NULL)
00317                 return (FALSE);
00318         for (i=0; i<ntext; ++i)
00319                 lputc(lp, i, text[i]);
00320         bufferp->b_linep->l_bp->l_fp = lp;       /* Hook onto the end    */
00321         lp->l_bp = bufferp->b_linep->l_bp;
00322         bufferp->b_linep->l_bp = lp;
00323         lp->l_fp = bufferp->b_linep;
00324         if (bufferp->b_dotp == bufferp->b_linep)  /* If "." is at the end */
00325                 bufferp->b_dotp = lp;            /* move it to new line  */
00326         return (TRUE);
00327 }
00328 
00329 /*
00330  * Look through the list of
00331  * buffers. Return TRUE if there
00332  * are any changed buffers. Buffers
00333  * that hold magic internal stuff are
00334  * not considered; who cares if the
00335  * list of buffer names is hacked.
00336  * Return FALSE if no buffers
00337  * have been changed.
00338  */
00339 globle int anycb()
00340 {
00341         register BUFFER *bp;
00342 
00343         bp = bheadp;
00344         while (bp != NULL) {
00345                 if ((bp->b_flag&BFTEMP)==0 && (bp->b_flag&BFCHG)!=0)
00346                         return (TRUE);
00347                 bp = bp->b_bufp;
00348         }
00349         return (FALSE);
00350 }

00352 /*
00353  * Find a buffer, by name. Return a pointer
00354  * to the BUFFER structure associated with it. If
00355  * the named buffer is found, but is a TEMP buffer (like
00356  * the buffer list) conplain. If the buffer is not found
00357  * and the "cflag" is TRUE, create it. The "bflag" is
00358  * the settings for the flags in in buffer.
00359  */
00360 globle BUFFER  *bfind(
00361   void *theEnv,
00362 char   *bname,
00363 int cflag,
00364 int bflag)
00365 {
00366         register BUFFER *bp;
00367         register LINE   *lp;
00368 
00369         bp = bheadp;
00370         while (bp != NULL) {
00371                 if (strcmp(bname, bp->b_bname) == 0) {
00372                         if ((bp->b_flag&BFTEMP) != 0) {
00373                                 mlwrite("Cannot select builtin buffer");
00374                                 return (NULL);
00375                         }
00376                         return (bp);
00377                 }
00378                 bp = bp->b_bufp;
00379         }
00380         if (cflag != FALSE) {
00381                 if ((bp=(BUFFER *)genalloc(theEnv,(unsigned) sizeof(BUFFER))) == NULL)
00382                         return (NULL);
00383                 if ((lp=lalloc(theEnv,0)) == NULL) {
00384                         genfree(theEnv,(void *) bp,(unsigned) sizeof(BUFFER));
00385                         return (NULL);
00386                 }
00387                 bp->b_bufp  = bheadp;
00388                 bheadp = bp;
00389                 bp->b_dotp  = lp;
00390                 bp->b_doto  = 0;
00391                 bp->b_markp = NULL;
00392                 bp->b_marko = 0;
00393                 bp->b_flag  = (char) bflag;
00394                 bp->b_nwnd  = 0;
00395                 bp->b_linep = lp;
00396                 genstrcpy(bp->b_fname, "");
00397                 genstrcpy(bp->b_bname, bname);
00398                 lp->l_fp = lp;
00399                 lp->l_bp = lp;
00400         }
00401         return (bp);
00402 }
00403 
00404 /*
00405  * This routine blows away all of the text
00406  * in a buffer. If the buffer is marked as changed
00407  * then we ask if it is ok to blow it away; this is
00408  * to save the user the grief of losing text. The
00409  * window chain is nearly always wrong if this gets
00410  * called; the caller must arrange for the updates
00411  * that are required. Return TRUE if everything
00412  * looks good.
00413  */
00414 globle int bclear(
00415   void *theEnv,
00416   BUFFER *bp)
00417 {
00418         register LINE   *lp;
00419         register int    s;
00420 
00421         if ((bp->b_flag&BFTEMP) == 0            /* Not scratch buffer.  */
00422            && (bp->b_flag&BFCHG) != 0              /* Something changed    */
00423            && (s=mlyesno(theEnv,"Discard changes")) != TRUE)
00424                 return (s);
00425         bp->b_flag  &= ~BFCHG;                  /* Not changed          */
00426 
00427         while ((lp=lforw(bp->b_linep)) != bp->b_linep)
00428                 lfree(theEnv,lp);
00429         bp->b_dotp  = bp->b_linep;              /* Fix "."              */
00430         bp->b_doto  = 0;
00431         bp->b_markp = NULL;                     /* Invalidate "mark"    */
00432         bp->b_marko = 0;
00433         return (TRUE);
00434 }

00436 /* ==========================================================================
00437  *                         LINE MANAGEMENT FUNCTIONS
00438  * ==========================================================================
00439  */
00440 
00441 /*
00442  * The functions in this section are a general set of line management utilities.
00443  * They are the only routines that touch the text. They also touch the buffer
00444  * and window structures, to make sure that the necessary updating gets done.
00445  * There are routines in this section that handle the kill buffer too. It isn't
00446  * here for any good reason.
00447  *
00448  * Note that this code only updates the dot and mark values in the window list.
00449  * Since all the code acts on the current window, the buffer that we are
00450  * editing must be being displayed, which means that "b_nwnd" is non zero,
00451  * which means that the dot and mark values in the buffer headers are nonsense.
00452  */
00453 
00454 /*
00455  * This routine allocates a block of memory large enough to hold a LINE
00456  * containing "used" characters. The block is always rounded up a bit. Return
00457  * a pointer to the new block, or NULL if there isn't any memory left. Print a
00458  * message in the message line if no space.
00459  */
00460 globle LINE    *lalloc(
00461   void *theEnv,
00462   int    used)
00463 {
00464         register LINE   *lp;
00465         register int    size;
00466 
00467         size = (used+NBLOCK-1) & ~(NBLOCK-1);
00468         if (size == 0)                          /* Assume that an empty */
00469                 size = NBLOCK;                  /* line is for type-in. */
00470         lp = (LINE *) genalloc(theEnv,(unsigned) sizeof(LINE)+size);
00471         lp->l_size = size;
00472         lp->l_used = used;
00473         return (lp);
00474 }
00475 
00476 /*
00477  * Delete line "lp". Fix all of the links that might point at it (they are
00478  * moved to offset 0 of the next line. Unlink the line from whatever buffer it
00479  * might be in. Release the memory. The buffers are updated too; the magic
00480  * conditions described in the above comments don't hold here.
00481  */
00482 globle void lfree(
00483   void *theEnv,
00484   LINE   *lp)
00485 {
00486         register BUFFER *bp;
00487         register WINDOW *wp;
00488 
00489         wp = wheadp;
00490         while (wp != NULL) {
00491                 if (wp->w_linep == lp)
00492                         wp->w_linep = lp->l_fp;
00493                 if (wp->w_dotp  == lp) {
00494                         wp->w_dotp  = lp->l_fp;
00495                         wp->w_doto  = 0;
00496                 }
00497                 if (wp->w_markp == lp) {
00498                         wp->w_markp = lp->l_fp;
00499                         wp->w_marko = 0;
00500                 }
00501                 wp = wp->w_wndp;
00502         }
00503         bp = bheadp;
00504         while (bp != NULL) {
00505                 if (bp->b_nwnd == 0) {
00506                         if (bp->b_dotp  == lp) {
00507                                 bp->b_dotp = lp->l_fp;
00508                                 bp->b_doto = 0;
00509                         }
00510                         if (bp->b_markp == lp) {
00511                                 bp->b_markp = lp->l_fp;
00512                                 bp->b_marko = 0;
00513                         }
00514                 }
00515                 bp = bp->b_bufp;
00516         }
00517         lp->l_bp->l_fp = lp->l_fp;
00518         lp->l_fp->l_bp = lp->l_bp;
00519         genfree(theEnv,(void *) lp, (unsigned) (sizeof(LINE) + lp->l_size));
00520 }
00521 
00522 /*
00523  * This routine gets called when a character is changed in place in the current
00524  * buffer. It updates all of the required flags in the buffer and window
00525  * system. The flag used is passed as an argument; if the buffer is being
00526  * displayed in more than 1 window we change EDIT t HARD. Set MODE if the
00527  * mode line needs to be updated (the "*" has to be set).
00528  */
00529 globle void lchange(
00530 int    flag)
00531 {
00532         register WINDOW *wp;
00533 
00534         if (curbp->b_nwnd != 1)                 /* Ensure hard.         */
00535                 flag = WFHARD;
00536         if ((curbp->b_flag&BFCHG) == 0) {       /* First change, so     */
00537                 flag |= WFMODE;                 /* update mode lines.   */
00538                 curbp->b_flag |= BFCHG;
00539         }
00540         wp = wheadp;
00541         while (wp != NULL) {
00542                 if (wp->w_bufp == curbp)
00543                         wp->w_flag |= flag;
00544                 wp = wp->w_wndp;
00545         }
00546 }
00547 
00548 /*
00549  * Insert "n" copies of the character "c" at the current location of dot. In
00550  * the easy case all that happens is the text is stored in the line. In the
00551  * hard case, the line has to be reallocated. When the window list is updated,
00552  * take special care; I screwed it up once. You always update dot in the
00553  * current window. You update mark, and a dot in another window, if it is
00554  * greater than the place where you did the insert. Return TRUE if all is
00555  * well, and FALSE on errors.
00556  */
00557 globle int linsert(
00558   void *theEnv,
00559   int n,
00560   int c)
00561 {
00562         register char   *cp1;
00563         register char   *cp2;
00564         register LINE   *lp1;
00565         register LINE   *lp2;
00566         register LINE   *lp3;
00567         register int    doto;
00568         register int    i;
00569         register WINDOW *wp;
00570 
00571         lchange(WFEDIT);
00572         lp1 = curwp->w_dotp;                    /* Current line         */
00573         if (lp1 == curbp->b_linep) {            /* At the end: special  */
00574                 if (curwp->w_doto != 0) {
00575                         mlwrite("bug: linsert");
00576                         return (FALSE);
00577                 }
00578                 if ((lp2=lalloc(theEnv,n)) == NULL)    /* Allocate new line    */
00579                         return (FALSE);
00580                 lp3 = lp1->l_bp;                /* Previous line        */
00581                 lp3->l_fp = lp2;                /* Link in              */
00582                 lp2->l_fp = lp1;
00583                 lp1->l_bp = lp2;
00584                 lp2->l_bp = lp3;
00585                 for (i=0; i<n; ++i)
00586                         lp2->l_text[i] = (char) c;
00587                 curwp->w_dotp = lp2;
00588                 curwp->w_doto = n;
00589                 return (TRUE);
00590         }
00591         doto = curwp->w_doto;                   /* Save for later.      */
00592         if (lp1->l_used+n > lp1->l_size) {      /* Hard: reallocate     */
00593                 if ((lp2=lalloc(theEnv,lp1->l_used+n)) == NULL)
00594                         return (FALSE);
00595                 cp1 = &lp1->l_text[0];
00596                 cp2 = &lp2->l_text[0];
00597                 while (cp1 != &lp1->l_text[doto])
00598                         *cp2++ = *cp1++;
00599                 cp2 += n;
00600                 while (cp1 != &lp1->l_text[lp1->l_used])
00601                         *cp2++ = *cp1++;
00602                 lp1->l_bp->l_fp = lp2;
00603                 lp2->l_fp = lp1->l_fp;
00604                 lp1->l_fp->l_bp = lp2;
00605                 lp2->l_bp = lp1->l_bp;
00606                 genfree(theEnv,(void *) lp1, (unsigned) (sizeof(LINE) + lp1->l_size));
00607         } else {                                /* Easy: in place       */
00608                 lp2 = lp1;                      /* Pretend new line     */
00609                 lp2->l_used += n;
00610                 cp2 = &lp1->l_text[lp1->l_used];
00611                 cp1 = cp2-n;
00612                 while (cp1 != &lp1->l_text[doto])
00613                         *--cp2 = *--cp1;
00614         }
00615         for (i=0; i<n; ++i)                     /* Add the characters   */
00616                 lp2->l_text[doto+i] = (char) c;
00617         wp = wheadp;                            /* Update windows       */
00618         while (wp != NULL) {
00619                 if (wp->w_linep == lp1)
00620                         wp->w_linep = lp2;
00621                 if (wp->w_dotp == lp1) {
00622                         wp->w_dotp = lp2;
00623                         if (wp==curwp || wp->w_doto>doto)
00624                                 wp->w_doto += n;
00625                 }
00626                 if (wp->w_markp == lp1) {
00627                         wp->w_markp = lp2;
00628                         if (wp->w_marko > doto)
00629                                 wp->w_marko += n;
00630                 }
00631                 wp = wp->w_wndp;
00632         }
00633         return (TRUE);
00634 }
00635 
00636 /*
00637  * Insert a newline into the buffer at the current location of dot in the
00638  * current window. The funny ass-backwards way it does things is not a botch;
00639  * it just makes the last line in the file not a special case. Return TRUE if
00640  * everything works out and FALSE on error (memory allocation failure). The
00641  * update of dot and mark is a bit easier then in the above case, because the
00642  * split forces more updating.
00643  */
00644 globle int lnewline(
00645   void *theEnv)
00646 {
00647         register char   *cp1;
00648         register char   *cp2;
00649         register LINE   *lp1;
00650         register LINE   *lp2;
00651         register int    doto;
00652         register WINDOW *wp;
00653 
00654         lchange(WFHARD);
00655         lp1  = curwp->w_dotp;                   /* Get the address and  */
00656         doto = curwp->w_doto;                   /* offset of "."        */
00657         if ((lp2=lalloc(theEnv,doto)) == NULL)         /* New first half line  */
00658                 return (FALSE);
00659         cp1 = &lp1->l_text[0];                  /* Shuffle text around  */
00660         cp2 = &lp2->l_text[0];
00661         while (cp1 != &lp1->l_text[doto])
00662                 *cp2++ = *cp1++;
00663         cp2 = &lp1->l_text[0];
00664         while (cp1 != &lp1->l_text[lp1->l_used])
00665                 *cp2++ = *cp1++;
00666         lp1->l_used -= doto;
00667         lp2->l_bp = lp1->l_bp;
00668         lp1->l_bp = lp2;
00669         lp2->l_bp->l_fp = lp2;
00670         lp2->l_fp = lp1;
00671         wp = wheadp;                            /* Windows              */
00672         while (wp != NULL) {
00673                 if (wp->w_linep == lp1)
00674                         wp->w_linep = lp2;
00675                 if (wp->w_dotp == lp1) {
00676                         if (wp->w_doto < doto)
00677                                 wp->w_dotp = lp2;
00678                         else
00679                                 wp->w_doto -= doto;
00680                 }
00681                 if (wp->w_markp == lp1) {
00682                         if (wp->w_marko < doto)
00683                                 wp->w_markp = lp2;
00684                         else
00685                                 wp->w_marko -= doto;
00686                 }
00687                 wp = wp->w_wndp;
00688         }
00689         return (TRUE);
00690 }
00691 
00692 /*
00693  * This function deletes "n" bytes, starting at dot. It understands how do deal
00694  * with end of lines, etc. It returns TRUE if all of the characters were
00695  * deleted, and FALSE if they were not (because dot ran into the end of the
00696  * buffer. The "kflag" is TRUE if the text should be put in the kill buffer.
00697  */
00698 globle int ldelete(
00699   void *theEnv,
00700   long n,
00701   int kflag)
00702 {
00703         register char   *cp1;
00704         register char   *cp2;
00705         register LINE   *dotp;
00706         register int    doto;
00707         register int    chunk;
00708         register WINDOW *wp;
00709 
00710         while (n != 0) {
00711                 dotp = curwp->w_dotp;
00712                 doto = curwp->w_doto;
00713                 if (dotp == curbp->b_linep)     /* Hit end of buffer.   */
00714                         return (FALSE);
00715                 chunk = dotp->l_used-doto;      /* Size of chunk.       */
00716                 if (chunk > (int) n)
00717                         chunk = (int) n;
00718                 if (chunk == 0) {               /* End of line, merge.  */
00719                         lchange(WFHARD);
00720                         if (ldelnewline(theEnv) == FALSE
00721                         || (kflag!=FALSE && kinsert(theEnv,'\n')==FALSE))
00722                                 return (FALSE);
00723                         --n;
00724                         continue;
00725                 }
00726                 lchange(WFEDIT);
00727                 cp1 = &dotp->l_text[doto];      /* Scrunch text.        */
00728                 cp2 = cp1 + chunk;
00729                 if (kflag != FALSE) {           /* Kill?                */
00730                         while (cp1 != cp2) {
00731                                 if (kinsert(theEnv,*cp1) == FALSE)
00732                                         return (FALSE);
00733                                 ++cp1;
00734                         }
00735                         cp1 = &dotp->l_text[doto];
00736                 }
00737                 while (cp2 != &dotp->l_text[dotp->l_used])
00738                         *cp1++ = *cp2++;
00739                 dotp->l_used -= chunk;
00740                 wp = wheadp;                    /* Fix windows          */
00741                 while (wp != NULL) {
00742                         if (wp->w_dotp==dotp && wp->w_doto>=doto) {
00743                                 wp->w_doto -= chunk;
00744                                 if (wp->w_doto < doto)
00745                                         wp->w_doto = doto;
00746                         }
00747                         if (wp->w_markp==dotp && wp->w_marko>=doto) {
00748                                 wp->w_marko -= chunk;
00749                                 if (wp->w_marko < doto)
00750                                         wp->w_marko = doto;
00751                         }
00752                         wp = wp->w_wndp;
00753                 }
00754                 n -= chunk;
00755         }
00756         return (TRUE);
00757 }
00758 
00759 /*
00760  * Delete a newline. Join the current line with the next line. If the next line
00761  * is the magic header line always return TRUE; merging the last line with the
00762  * header line can be thought of as always being a successful operation, even
00763  * if nothing is done, and this makes the kill buffer work "right". Easy cases
00764  * can be done by shuffling data around. Hard cases require that lines be moved
00765  * about in memory. Return FALSE on error and TRUE if all looks ok. Called by
00766  * "ldelete" only.
00767  */
00768 globle int ldelnewline(
00769   void *theEnv)
00770 {
00771         register char   *cp1;
00772         register char   *cp2;
00773         register LINE   *lp1;
00774         register LINE   *lp2;
00775         register LINE   *lp3;
00776         register WINDOW *wp;
00777 
00778         lp1 = curwp->w_dotp;
00779         lp2 = lp1->l_fp;
00780         if (lp2 == curbp->b_linep) {            /* At the buffer end.   */
00781                 if (lp1->l_used == 0)           /* Blank line.          */
00782                         lfree(theEnv,lp1);
00783                 return (TRUE);
00784         }
00785         if (lp2->l_used <= lp1->l_size-lp1->l_used) {
00786                 cp1 = &lp1->l_text[lp1->l_used];
00787                 cp2 = &lp2->l_text[0];
00788                 while (cp2 != &lp2->l_text[lp2->l_used])
00789                         *cp1++ = *cp2++;
00790                 wp = wheadp;
00791                 while (wp != NULL) {
00792                         if (wp->w_linep == lp2)
00793                                 wp->w_linep = lp1;
00794                         if (wp->w_dotp == lp2) {
00795                                 wp->w_dotp  = lp1;
00796                                 wp->w_doto += lp1->l_used;
00797                         }
00798                         if (wp->w_markp == lp2) {
00799                                 wp->w_markp  = lp1;
00800                                 wp->w_marko += lp1->l_used;
00801                         }
00802                         wp = wp->w_wndp;
00803                 }
00804                 lp1->l_used += lp2->l_used;
00805                 lp1->l_fp = lp2->l_fp;
00806                 lp2->l_fp->l_bp = lp1;
00807                 genfree(theEnv,(void *) lp2, (unsigned) (sizeof(LINE) + lp2->l_size));
00808                 return (TRUE);
00809         }
00810         if ((lp3=lalloc(theEnv,lp1->l_used+lp2->l_used)) == NULL)
00811                 return (FALSE);
00812         cp1 = &lp1->l_text[0];
00813         cp2 = &lp3->l_text[0];
00814         while (cp1 != &lp1->l_text[lp1->l_used])
00815                 *cp2++ = *cp1++;
00816         cp1 = &lp2->l_text[0];
00817         while (cp1 != &lp2->l_text[lp2->l_used])
00818                 *cp2++ = *cp1++;
00819         lp1->l_bp->l_fp = lp3;
00820         lp3->l_fp = lp2->l_fp;
00821         lp2->l_fp->l_bp = lp3;
00822         lp3->l_bp = lp1->l_bp;
00823         wp = wheadp;
00824         while (wp != NULL) {
00825                 if (wp->w_linep==lp1 || wp->w_linep==lp2)
00826                         wp->w_linep = lp3;
00827                 if (wp->w_dotp == lp1)
00828                         wp->w_dotp  = lp3;
00829                 else if (wp->w_dotp == lp2) {
00830                         wp->w_dotp  = lp3;
00831                         wp->w_doto += lp1->l_used;
00832                 }
00833                 if (wp->w_markp == lp1)
00834                         wp->w_markp  = lp3;
00835                 else if (wp->w_markp == lp2) {
00836                         wp->w_markp  = lp3;
00837                         wp->w_marko += lp1->l_used;
00838                 }
00839                 wp = wp->w_wndp;
00840         }
00841         genfree(theEnv,(void *) lp1, (unsigned) (sizeof(LINE) + lp1->l_size));
00842         genfree(theEnv,(void *) lp2, (unsigned) (sizeof(LINE) + lp2->l_size));
00843         return (TRUE);
00844 }
00845 
00846 /*
00847  * Delete all of the text saved in the kill buffer. Called by commands when a
00848  * new kill context is being created. The kill buffer array is released, just
00849  * in case the buffer has grown to immense size. No errors.
00850  */
00851 globle void kdelete(
00852   void *theEnv)
00853 {
00854         if (kbufp != NULL) {
00855                 genfree(theEnv,(void *) kbufp, (unsigned) ksize);
00856                 kbufp = NULL;
00857                 kused = 0;
00858                 ksize = 0;
00859         }
00860 }
00861 
00862 /*
00863  * Insert a character to the kill buffer, enlarging the buffer if there isn't
00864  * any room. Always grow the buffer in chunks, on the assumption that if you
00865  * put something in the kill buffer you are going to put more stuff there too
00866  * later. Return TRUE if all is well, and FALSE on errors.
00867  */
00868 globle int kinsert(
00869   void *theEnv,
00870   int c)
00871 {
00872 #if  WIN_MVC || WIN_BTC
00873         char *nbufp;
00874 #else
00875         register char   *nbufp;
00876 #endif
00877         register int    i;
00878 
00879         if (kused == ksize) {
00880                 if ((nbufp= (char *) genalloc(theEnv,(unsigned) ksize+KBLOCK)) == NULL)
00881                         return (FALSE);
00882                 for (i=0; i<ksize; ++i)
00883                         nbufp[i] = kbufp[i];
00884                 if (kbufp != NULL)
00885                         genfree(theEnv,(void *) kbufp, (unsigned) ksize);
00886                 kbufp  = nbufp;
00887                 ksize += KBLOCK;
00888         }
00889         kbufp[kused++] = (char) c;
00890         return (TRUE);
00891 }
00892 
00893 /*
00894  * This function gets characters from the kill buffer. If the character index
00895  * "n" is off the end, it returns "-1". This lets the caller just scan along
00896  * until it gets a "-1" back.
00897  */
00898 globle int kremove(
00899 int n)
00900 {
00901         if (n >= kused)
00902                 return (-1);
00903         else
00904                 return (kbufp[n] & 0xFF);
00905 }
00906 
00907 
00908 /* ==========================================================================
00909  *                        WINDOW MANAGEMENT FUNCTIONS
00910  * ==========================================================================
00911  */
00912 
00913 /*
00914  * Again, some of these functions are internal, and some are
00915  * attached to keys that the user actually types.
00916  */
00917 
00918 /*
00919  * Reposition dot in the current window to line "n". If the argument is
00920  * positive, it is that line. If it is negative it is that line from the
00921  * bottom. If it is 0 the window is centered (this is what the standard
00922  * redisplay code does). With no argument it defaults to 1. Bound to M-!.
00923  * Because of the default, it works like in Gosling.
00924  */
00925 #if WIN_BTC
00926 #pragma argsused
00927 #endif
00928 globle int reposition(
00929   void *theEnv,
00930   int f,
00931   int n)
00932     {
00933     curwp->w_force = (char) n;
00934     curwp->w_flag |= WFFORCE;
00935     return (TRUE);
00936     }
00937 
00938 /*
00939  * Refresh the screen. With no argument, it just does the refresh. With an
00940  * argument it recenters "." in the current window. Bound to "C-L".
00941  */
00942 #if WIN_BTC
00943 #pragma argsused
00944 #endif
00945 globle int EditorRefresh(
00946   void *theEnv,
00947   int f,
00948   int n)
00949     {
00950     if (f == FALSE)
00951         sgarbf = TRUE;
00952     else
00953         {
00954         curwp->w_force = 0;             /* Center dot. */
00955         curwp->w_flag |= WFFORCE;
00956         }
00957 
00958     return (TRUE);
00959     }
00960 
00961 /*
00962  * The command make the next window (next => down the screen) the current
00963  * window. There are no real errors, although the command does nothing if
00964  * there is only 1 window on the screen. Bound to "C-X C-N".
00965  */
00966 #if WIN_BTC
00967 #pragma argsused
00968 #endif
00969 globle int nextwind(
00970   void *theEnv,
00971   int f,
00972   int n)
00973     {
00974     register WINDOW *wp;
00975 
00976     if ((wp = curwp->w_wndp) == NULL)
00977         wp = wheadp;
00978 
00979     curwp = wp;
00980     curbp = wp->w_bufp;
00981     return (TRUE);
00982     }
00983 
00984 /*
00985  * This command makes the previous window (previous => up the screen) the
00986  * current window. There arn't any errors, although the command does not do a
00987  * lot if there is 1 window.
00988  */
00989 #if WIN_BTC
00990 #pragma argsused
00991 #endif
00992 globle int prevwind(
00993   void *theEnv,
00994   int f,
00995   int n)
00996     {
00997     register WINDOW *wp1;
00998     register WINDOW *wp2;
00999 
01000     wp1 = wheadp;
01001     wp2 = curwp;
01002 
01003     if (wp1 == wp2)
01004         wp2 = NULL;
01005 
01006     while (wp1->w_wndp != wp2)
01007         wp1 = wp1->w_wndp;
01008 
01009     curwp = wp1;
01010     curbp = wp1->w_bufp;
01011     return (TRUE);
01012     }
01013 
01014 /*
01015  * This command moves the current window down by "arg" lines. Recompute the
01016  * top line in the window. The move up and move down code is almost completely
01017  * the same; most of the work has to do with reframing the window, and picking
01018  * a new dot. We share the code by having "move down" just be an interface to
01019  * "move up". Magic. Bound to "C-X C-N".
01020  */
01021 globle int mvdnwind(
01022   void *theEnv,
01023   int f,
01024   int n)
01025     {
01026     return (mvupwind(theEnv,f, -n));
01027     }
01028 
01029 /*
01030  * Move the current window up by "arg" lines. Recompute the new top line of
01031  * the window. Look to see if "." is still on the screen. If it is, you win.
01032  * If it isn't, then move "." to center it in the new framing of the window
01033  * (this command does not really move "."; it moves the frame). Bound to
01034  * "C-X C-P".
01035  */
01036 #if WIN_BTC
01037 #pragma argsused
01038 #endif
01039 globle int mvupwind(
01040   void *theEnv,
01041   int f,
01042   int n)
01043     {
01044     register LINE *lp;
01045     register int i;
01046 
01047     lp = curwp->w_linep;
01048 
01049     if (n < 0)
01050         {
01051         while (n++ && lp!=curbp->b_linep)
01052             lp = lforw(lp);
01053         }
01054     else
01055         {
01056         while (n-- && lback(lp)!=curbp->b_linep)
01057             lp = lback(lp);
01058         }
01059 
01060     curwp->w_linep = lp;
01061     curwp->w_flag |= WFHARD;            /* Mode line is OK. */
01062 
01063     for (i = 0; i < curwp->w_ntrows; ++i)
01064         {
01065         if (lp == curwp->w_dotp)
01066             return (TRUE);
01067         if (lp == curbp->b_linep)
01068             break;
01069         lp = lforw(lp);
01070         }
01071 
01072     lp = curwp->w_linep;
01073     i  = curwp->w_ntrows/2;
01074 
01075     while (i-- && lp != curbp->b_linep)
01076         lp = lforw(lp);
01077 
01078     curwp->w_dotp  = lp;
01079     curwp->w_doto  = 0;
01080     return (TRUE);
01081     }
01082 
01083 /*
01084  * This command makes the current window the only window on the screen. Bound
01085  * to "C-X 1". Try to set the framing so that "." does not have to move on the
01086  * display. Some care has to be taken to keep the values of dot and mark in
01087  * the buffer structures right if the distruction of a window makes a buffer
01088  * become undisplayed.
01089  */
01090 #if WIN_BTC
01091 #pragma argsused
01092 #endif
01093 globle int onlywind(
01094   void *theEnv,
01095   int f,
01096   int n)
01097 {
01098         register WINDOW *wp;
01099         register LINE   *lp;
01100         register int    i;
01101 
01102         while (wheadp != curwp) {
01103                 wp = wheadp;
01104                 wheadp = wp->w_wndp;
01105                 if (--wp->w_bufp->b_nwnd == 0) {
01106                         wp->w_bufp->b_dotp  = wp->w_dotp;
01107                         wp->w_bufp->b_doto  = wp->w_doto;
01108                         wp->w_bufp->b_markp = wp->w_markp;
01109                         wp->w_bufp->b_marko = wp->w_marko;
01110                 }
01111                 genfree(theEnv,(void *) wp, (unsigned) sizeof(WINDOW));
01112         }
01113         while (curwp->w_wndp != NULL) {
01114                 wp = curwp->w_wndp;
01115                 curwp->w_wndp = wp->w_wndp;
01116                 if (--wp->w_bufp->b_nwnd == 0) {
01117                         wp->w_bufp->b_dotp  = wp->w_dotp;
01118                         wp->w_bufp->b_doto  = wp->w_doto;
01119                         wp->w_bufp->b_markp = wp->w_markp;
01120                         wp->w_bufp->b_marko = wp->w_marko;
01121                 }
01122                 genfree(theEnv,(void *) wp, (unsigned) sizeof(WINDOW));
01123         }
01124         lp = curwp->w_linep;
01125         i  = curwp->w_toprow;
01126         while (i!=0 && lback(lp)!=curbp->b_linep) {
01127                 --i;
01128                 lp = lback(lp);
01129         }
01130         curwp->w_toprow = 0;
01131         curwp->w_ntrows = (char) (term.t_nrow-1);
01132         curwp->w_linep  = lp;
01133         curwp->w_flag  |= WFMODE|WFHARD;
01134         return (TRUE);
01135 }
01136 
01137 /*
01138  * Split the current window. A window smaller than 3 lines cannot be split.
01139  * The only other error that is possible is a "malloc" failure allocating the
01140  * structure for the new window. Bound to "C-X 2".
01141  */
01142 #if WIN_BTC
01143 #pragma argsused
01144 #endif
01145 globle int splitwind(
01146   void *theEnv,
01147   int f,
01148   int n)
01149 {
01150         register WINDOW *wp;
01151         register LINE   *lp;
01152         register int    ntru;
01153         register int    ntrl;
01154         register int    ntrd;
01155         register WINDOW *wp1;
01156         register WINDOW *wp2;
01157 
01158         if (curwp->w_ntrows < 3) {
01159                 mlwrite("Cannot split a %d line window", curwp->w_ntrows);
01160                 return (FALSE);
01161         }
01162         if ((wp = (WINDOW *) genalloc(theEnv,(unsigned) sizeof(WINDOW))) == NULL) {
01163                 mlwrite("Cannot allocate WINDOW block");
01164                 return (FALSE);
01165         }
01166         ++curbp->b_nwnd;                        /* Displayed twice.     */
01167         wp->w_bufp  = curbp;
01168         wp->w_dotp  = curwp->w_dotp;
01169         wp->w_doto  = curwp->w_doto;
01170         wp->w_markp = curwp->w_markp;
01171         wp->w_marko = curwp->w_marko;
01172         wp->w_flag  = 0;
01173         wp->w_force = 0;
01174         ntru = (curwp->w_ntrows-1) / 2;         /* Upper size           */
01175         ntrl = (curwp->w_ntrows-1) - ntru;      /* Lower size           */
01176         lp = curwp->w_linep;
01177         ntrd = 0;
01178         while (lp != curwp->w_dotp) {
01179                 ++ntrd;
01180                 lp = lforw(lp);
01181         }
01182         lp = curwp->w_linep;
01183         if (ntrd <= ntru) {                     /* Old is upper window. */
01184                 if (ntrd == ntru)               /* Hit mode line.       */
01185                         lp = lforw(lp);
01186                 curwp->w_ntrows = (char) ntru;
01187                 wp->w_wndp = curwp->w_wndp;
01188                 curwp->w_wndp = wp;
01189                 wp->w_toprow = curwp->w_toprow+ntru+1;
01190                 wp->w_ntrows = (char) ntrl;
01191         } else {                                /* Old is lower window  */
01192                 wp1 = NULL;
01193                 wp2 = wheadp;
01194                 while (wp2 != curwp) {
01195                         wp1 = wp2;
01196                         wp2 = wp2->w_wndp;
01197                 }
01198                 if (wp1 == NULL)
01199                         wheadp = wp;
01200                 else
01201                         wp1->w_wndp = wp;
01202                 wp->w_wndp   = curwp;
01203                 wp->w_toprow = curwp->w_toprow;
01204                 wp->w_ntrows = (char) ntru;
01205                 ++ntru;                         /* Mode line.           */
01206                 curwp->w_toprow += (char) ntru;
01207                 curwp->w_ntrows  = (char) ntrl;
01208                 while (ntru--)
01209                         lp = lforw(lp);
01210         }
01211         curwp->w_linep = lp;                    /* Adjust the top lines */
01212         wp->w_linep = lp;                       /* if necessary.        */
01213         curwp->w_flag |= WFMODE|WFHARD;
01214         wp->w_flag |= WFMODE|WFHARD;
01215         return (TRUE);
01216 }
01217 
01218 /*
01219  * Enlarge the current window. Find the window that loses space. Make sure it
01220  * is big enough. If so, hack the window descriptions, and ask redisplay to do
01221  * all the hard work. You don't just set "force reframe" because dot would
01222  * move. Bound to "C-X Z".
01223  */
01224 globle int enlargewind(
01225   void *theEnv,
01226   int f,
01227   int n)
01228 {
01229         register WINDOW *adjwp;
01230         register LINE   *lp;
01231         register int    i;
01232 
01233         if (n < 0)
01234                 return (shrinkwind(theEnv,f, -n));
01235         if (wheadp->w_wndp == NULL) {
01236                 mlwrite("Only one window");
01237                 return (FALSE);
01238         }
01239         if ((adjwp=curwp->w_wndp) == NULL) {
01240                 adjwp = wheadp;
01241                 while (adjwp->w_wndp != curwp)
01242                         adjwp = adjwp->w_wndp;
01243         }
01244         if (adjwp->w_ntrows <= (char) n) {
01245                 mlwrite("Impossible change");
01246                 return (FALSE);
01247         }
01248         if (curwp->w_wndp == adjwp) {           /* Shrink below.        */
01249                 lp = adjwp->w_linep;
01250                 for (i=0; i<n && lp!=adjwp->w_bufp->b_linep; ++i)
01251                         lp = lforw(lp);
01252                 adjwp->w_linep  = lp;
01253                 adjwp->w_toprow += (char) n;
01254         } else {                                /* Shrink above.        */
01255                 lp = curwp->w_linep;
01256                 for (i=0; i<n && lback(lp)!=curbp->b_linep; ++i)
01257                         lp = lback(lp);
01258                 curwp->w_linep  = lp;
01259                 curwp->w_toprow -= (char) n;
01260         }
01261         curwp->w_ntrows += (char) n;
01262         adjwp->w_ntrows -= (char) n;
01263         curwp->w_flag |= WFMODE|WFHARD;
01264         adjwp->w_flag |= WFMODE|WFHARD;
01265         return (TRUE);
01266 }
01267 
01268 /*
01269  * Shrink the current window. Find the window that gains space. Hack at the
01270  * window descriptions. Ask the redisplay to do all the hard work. Bound to
01271  * "C-X C-Z".
01272  */
01273 globle int shrinkwind(
01274   void *theEnv,
01275   int f,
01276   int n)
01277 {
01278         register WINDOW *adjwp;
01279         register LINE   *lp;
01280         register int    i;
01281 
01282         if (n < 0)
01283                 return (enlargewind(theEnv,f, -n));
01284         if (wheadp->w_wndp == NULL) {
01285                 mlwrite("Only one window");
01286                 return (FALSE);
01287         }
01288         if ((adjwp=curwp->w_wndp) == NULL) {
01289                 adjwp = wheadp;
01290                 while (adjwp->w_wndp != curwp)
01291                         adjwp = adjwp->w_wndp;
01292         }
01293         if (curwp->w_ntrows <= (char) n) {
01294                 mlwrite("Impossible change");
01295                 return (FALSE);
01296         }
01297         if (curwp->w_wndp == adjwp) {           /* Grow below.          */
01298                 lp = adjwp->w_linep;
01299                 for (i=0; i<n && lback(lp)!=adjwp->w_bufp->b_linep; ++i)
01300                         lp = lback(lp);
01301                 adjwp->w_linep  = lp;
01302                 adjwp->w_toprow -= (char) n;
01303         } else {                                /* Grow above.          */
01304                 lp = curwp->w_linep;
01305                 for (i=0; i<n && lp!=curbp->b_linep; ++i)
01306                         lp = lforw(lp);
01307                 curwp->w_linep  = lp;
01308                 curwp->w_toprow += (char) n;
01309         }
01310         curwp->w_ntrows -= (char) n;
01311         adjwp->w_ntrows += (char) n;
01312         curwp->w_flag |= WFMODE|WFHARD;
01313         adjwp->w_flag |= WFMODE|WFHARD;
01314         return (TRUE);
01315 }
01316 
01317 /*
01318  * Pick a window for a pop-up. Split the screen if there is only one window.
01319  * Pick the uppermost window that isn't the current window. An LRU algorithm
01320  * might be better. Return a pointer, or NULL on error.
01321  */
01322 globle WINDOW  *wpopup(
01323   void *theEnv)
01324 {
01325         register WINDOW *wp;
01326 
01327         if (wheadp->w_wndp == NULL              /* Only 1 window        */
01328         && splitwind(theEnv,FALSE, 0) == FALSE)        /* and it won't split   */
01329                 return (NULL);
01330         wp = wheadp;                            /* Find window to use   */
01331         while (wp!=NULL && wp==curwp)
01332                 wp = wp->w_wndp;
01333         return (wp);
01334 }
01335 
01336 
01337 /* ==========================================================================
01338  *                        DISPLAY MANAGEMENT FUNCTIONS
01339  * ==========================================================================
01340  */
01341 
01342 /*
01343  * The functions in this section handle redisplay. There are two halves, the
01344  * ones that update the virtual display screen, and the ones that make the
01345  * physical display screen the same as the virtual display screen. These
01346  * functions use hints that are left in the windows by the commands.
01347  *
01348  * REVISION HISTORY:
01349  *
01350  * ?    Steve Wilhite, 1-Dec-85
01351  *      - massive cleanup on code.
01352  */
01353 
01354 #define WFDEBUG 0                       /* Window flag debug. */
01355 
01356 /*
01357  * Initialize the data structures used by the display code. The edge vectors
01358  * used to access the screens are set up. The operating system's terminal I/O
01359  * channel is set up. All the other things get initialized at compile time.
01360  * The original window has "WFCHG" set, so that it will get completely
01361  * redrawn on the first call to "update".
01362  */
01363 globle void vtinit(
01364   void *theEnv)
01365 {
01366     register int i;
01367 
01368     register VIDEO *vp;
01369 
01370     (*term.t_open)();
01371     vscreen = (VIDEO **) genalloc(theEnv,(unsigned) term.t_nrow*sizeof(VIDEO *));
01372 
01373     if (vscreen == NULL)
01374         exit(1);
01375 
01376     pscreen = (VIDEO **) genalloc(theEnv,(unsigned) term.t_nrow*sizeof(VIDEO *));
01377 
01378     if (pscreen == NULL)
01379         exit(1);
01380 
01381     for (i = 0; i < term.t_nrow; ++i)
01382         {
01383         vp = (VIDEO *) genalloc(theEnv,(unsigned) sizeof(VIDEO)+term.t_ncol);
01384 
01385         if (vp == NULL)
01386             exit(1);
01387 
01388         vscreen[i] = vp;
01389         vp = (VIDEO *) genalloc(theEnv,(unsigned) sizeof(VIDEO)+term.t_ncol);
01390 
01391         if (vp == NULL)
01392             exit(1);
01393 
01394         pscreen[i] = vp;
01395         }
01396 }
01397 
01398 /*
01399  * Clean up the virtual terminal system, in anticipation for a return to the
01400  * operating system. Move down to the last line and clear it out (the next
01401  * system prompt will be written in the line). Shut down the channel to the
01402  * terminal.
01403  */
01404 globle void vttidy()
01405 {
01406     movecursor(term.t_nrow, 0);
01407     (*term.t_eeol)();
01408     (*term.t_close)();
01409 }
01410 
01411 /*
01412  * Set the virtual cursor to the specified row and column on the virtual
01413  * screen. There is no checking for nonsense values; this might be a good
01414  * idea during the early stages.
01415  */
01416 globle void vtmove(
01417 int row,
01418 int col)
01419 {
01420     vtrow = row;
01421     vtcol = col;
01422 }
01423 
01424 /*
01425  * Write a character to the virtual screen. The virtual row and column are
01426  * updated. If the line is too long put a "$" in the last column. This routine
01427  * only puts printing characters into the virtual terminal buffers. Only
01428  * column overflow is checked.
01429  */
01430 globle void vtputc(
01431     int c)
01432 {
01433     register VIDEO      *vp;
01434 
01435     vp = vscreen[vtrow];
01436 
01437     if (vtcol >= term.t_ncol)
01438         vp->v_text[term.t_ncol - 1] = '$';
01439     else if (c == '\t')
01440         {
01441         do
01442             {
01443             vtputc(' ');
01444             }
01445         while ((vtcol&0x07) != 0);
01446         }
01447     else if (c < 0x20 || c == 0x7F)
01448         {
01449         vtputc('^');
01450         vtputc(c ^ 0x40);
01451         }
01452     else
01453         vp->v_text[vtcol++] = (char) c;
01454 }
01455 
01456 /*
01457  * Erase from the end of the software cursor to the end of the line on which
01458  * the software cursor is located.
01459  */
01460 globle void vteeol()
01461 {
01462     register VIDEO      *vp;
01463 
01464     vp = vscreen[vtrow];
01465     while (vtcol < term.t_ncol)
01466         vp->v_text[vtcol++] = ' ';
01467 }
01468 
01469 /*
01470  * Make sure that the display is right. This is a three part process. First,
01471  * scan through all of the windows looking for dirty ones. Check the framing,
01472  * and refresh the screen. Second, make sure that "currow" and "curcol" are
01473  * correct for the current window. Third, make the virtual and physical
01474  * screens the same.
01475  */
01476 globle void update()
01477 {
01478     register LINE *lp;
01479     register WINDOW *wp;
01480     register VIDEO *vp1;
01481     register VIDEO *vp2;
01482     register int i;
01483     register int j;
01484     register int c;
01485 
01486     wp = wheadp;
01487 
01488     while (wp != NULL)
01489         {
01490         /* Look at any window with update flags set on. */
01491 
01492         if (wp->w_flag != 0)
01493             {
01494             /* If not force reframe, check the framing. */
01495 
01496             if ((wp->w_flag & WFFORCE) == 0)
01497                 {
01498                 lp = wp->w_linep;
01499 
01500                 for (i = 0; i < wp->w_ntrows; ++i)
01501                     {
01502                     if (lp == wp->w_dotp)
01503                         goto out;
01504 
01505                     if (lp == wp->w_bufp->b_linep)
01506                         break;
01507 
01508                     lp = lforw(lp);
01509                     }
01510                 }
01511 
01512             /* Not acceptable, better compute a new value for the line at the
01513              * top of the window. Then set the "WFHARD" flag to force full
01514              * redraw.
01515              */
01516             i = wp->w_force;
01517 
01518             if (i > 0)
01519                 {
01520                 --i;
01521 
01522                 if (i >= wp->w_ntrows)
01523                   i = wp->w_ntrows-1;
01524                 }
01525             else if (i < 0)
01526                 {
01527                 i += wp->w_ntrows;
01528 
01529                 if (i < 0)
01530                     i = 0;
01531                 }
01532             else
01533                 i = wp->w_ntrows/2;
01534 
01535             lp = wp->w_dotp;
01536 
01537             while (i != 0 && lback(lp) != wp->w_bufp->b_linep)
01538                 {
01539                 --i;
01540                 lp = lback(lp);
01541                 }
01542 
01543             wp->w_linep = lp;
01544             wp->w_flag |= WFHARD;       /* Force full. */
01545 
01546 out:
01547             /* Try to use reduced update. Mode line update has its own special
01548              * flag. The fast update is used if the only thing to do is within
01549              * the line editing.
01550              */
01551             lp = wp->w_linep;
01552             i = wp->w_toprow;
01553 
01554             if ((wp->w_flag & ~WFMODE) == WFEDIT)
01555                 {
01556                 while (lp != wp->w_dotp)
01557                     {
01558                     ++i;
01559                     lp = lforw(lp);
01560                     }
01561 
01562                 vscreen[i]->v_flag |= VFCHG;
01563                 vtmove(i, 0);
01564 
01565                 for (j = 0; j < llength(lp); ++j)
01566                     vtputc(lgetc(lp, j));
01567 
01568                 vteeol();
01569                 }
01570              else if ((wp->w_flag & (WFEDIT | WFHARD)) != 0)
01571                 {
01572                 while (i < wp->w_toprow+wp->w_ntrows)
01573                     {
01574                     vscreen[i]->v_flag |= VFCHG;
01575                     vtmove(i, 0);
01576 
01577                     if (lp != wp->w_bufp->b_linep)
01578                         {
01579                         for (j = 0; j < llength(lp); ++j)
01580                             vtputc(lgetc(lp, j));
01581 
01582                         lp = lforw(lp);
01583                         }
01584 
01585                     vteeol();
01586                     ++i;
01587                     }
01588                 }
01589 #if ~WFDEBUG
01590             if ((wp->w_flag&WFMODE) != 0)
01591                 modeline(wp);
01592 
01593             wp->w_flag  = 0;
01594             wp->w_force = 0;
01595 #endif
01596             }
01597 #if WFDEBUG
01598         modeline(wp);
01599         wp->w_flag =  0;
01600         wp->w_force = 0;
01601 #endif
01602         wp = wp->w_wndp;
01603         }
01604 
01605     /* Always recompute the row and column number of the hardware cursor. This
01606      * is the only update for simple moves.
01607      */
01608     lp = curwp->w_linep;
01609     currow = curwp->w_toprow;
01610 
01611     while (lp != curwp->w_dotp)
01612         {
01613         ++currow;
01614         lp = lforw(lp);
01615         }
01616 
01617     curcol = 0;
01618     i = 0;
01619 
01620     while (i < curwp->w_doto)
01621         {
01622         c = lgetc(lp, i++);
01623 
01624         if (c == '\t')
01625             curcol |= 0x07;
01626         else if (c < 0x20 || c == 0x7F)
01627             ++curcol;
01628 
01629         ++curcol;
01630         }
01631 /*sprintf(prompt,"Currow: %d  curcol: %d w_toprow: %d", currow, getccol(FALSE),
01632 curwp->w_toprow);
01633 mlwrite(prompt);*/
01634     if (curcol >= term.t_ncol)          /* Long line. */
01635         curcol = term.t_ncol-1;
01636 
01637     /* Special hacking if the screen is garbage. Clear the hardware screen,
01638      * and update your copy to agree with it. Set all the virtual screen
01639      * change bits, to force a full update.
01640      */
01641     if (sgarbf != FALSE)
01642         {
01643         for (i = 0; i < term.t_nrow; ++i)
01644             {
01645             vscreen[i]->v_flag |= VFCHG;
01646             vp1 = pscreen[i];
01647             for (j = 0; j < term.t_ncol; ++j)
01648                 vp1->v_text[j] = ' ';
01649             }
01650 
01651         movecursor(0, 0);               /* Erase the screen. */
01652         (*term.t_eeop)();
01653         sgarbf = FALSE;                 /* Erase-page clears */
01654         mpresf = FALSE;                 /* the message area. */
01655         }
01656 
01657     /* Make sure that the physical and virtual displays agree. Unlike before,
01658      * the "updateline" code is only called with a line that has been updated
01659      * for sure.
01660      */
01661     for (i = 0; i < term.t_nrow; ++i)
01662         {
01663         vp1 = vscreen[i];
01664 
01665         if ((vp1->v_flag&VFCHG) != 0)
01666             {
01667             vp1->v_flag &= ~VFCHG;
01668             vp2 = pscreen[i];
01669             updateline(i, &vp1->v_text[0], &vp2->v_text[0]);
01670             }
01671         }
01672 
01673     /* Finally, update the hardware cursor and flush out buffers. */
01674 
01675     movecursor(currow, curcol);
01676     (*term.t_flush)();
01677 }
01678 
01679 /*
01680  * Update a single line. This does not know how to use insert or delete
01681  * character sequences; we are using VT52 functionality. Update the physical
01682  * row and column variables. It does try an exploit erase to end of line. The
01683  * RAINBOW version of this routine uses fast video.
01684  */
01685 globle void updateline(
01686     int row,
01687     char vline[],
01688     char pline[])
01689 {
01690     register char *cp1;
01691     register char *cp2;
01692     register char *cp3;
01693     register char *cp4;
01694     register char *cp5;
01695     register int nbflag;
01696 
01697     cp1 = &vline[0];                    /* Compute left match.  */
01698     cp2 = &pline[0];
01699 
01700     while (cp1!=&vline[term.t_ncol] && cp1[0]==cp2[0])
01701         {
01702         ++cp1;
01703         ++cp2;
01704         }
01705 
01706     /* This can still happen, even though we only call this routine on changed
01707      * lines. A hard update is always done when a line splits, a massive
01708      * change is done, or a buffer is displayed twice. This optimizes out most
01709      * of the excess updating. A lot of computes are used, but these tend to
01710      * be hard operations that do a lot of update, so I don't really care.
01711      */
01712     if (cp1 == &vline[term.t_ncol])             /* All equal. */
01713         return;
01714 
01715     nbflag = FALSE;
01716     cp3 = &vline[term.t_ncol];          /* Compute right match. */
01717     cp4 = &pline[term.t_ncol];
01718 
01719     while (cp3[-1] == cp4[-1])
01720         {
01721         --cp3;
01722         --cp4;
01723         if (cp3[0] != ' ')              /* Note if any nonblank */
01724             nbflag = TRUE;              /* in right match. */
01725         }
01726 
01727     cp5 = cp3;
01728 
01729     if (nbflag == FALSE)                /* Erase to EOL ? */
01730         {
01731         while (cp5!=cp1 && cp5[-1]==' ')
01732             --cp5;
01733 
01734         if (cp3-cp5 <= 3)               /* Use only if erase is */
01735             cp5 = cp3;                  /* fewer characters. */
01736         }
01737 
01738     movecursor(row, (int) (cp1-&vline[0]));     /* Go to start of line. */
01739 
01740     while (cp1 != cp5)                  /* Ordinary. */
01741         {
01742         (*term.t_putchar)(*cp1);
01743         ++ttcol;
01744         *cp2++ = *cp1++;
01745         }
01746 
01747     if (cp5 != cp3)                     /* Erase. */
01748         {
01749         (*term.t_eeol)();
01750         while (cp1 != cp3)
01751             *cp2++ = *cp1++;
01752         }
01753 }
01754 
01755 /*
01756  * Redisplay the mode line for the window pointed to by the "wp". This is the
01757  * only routine that has any idea of how the modeline is formatted. You can
01758  * change the modeline format by hacking at this routine. Called by "update"
01759  * any time there is a dirty window.
01760  */
01761 globle void modeline(
01762     WINDOW *wp)
01763 {
01764     register char *cp;
01765     register int c;
01766     register int n;
01767     register BUFFER *bp;
01768 
01769     n = wp->w_toprow+wp->w_ntrows;              /* Location. */
01770     vscreen[n]->v_flag |= VFCHG;                /* Redraw next time. */
01771     vtmove(n, 0);                               /* Seek to right line. */
01772     vtputc('-');
01773     bp = wp->w_bufp;
01774 
01775     if ((bp->b_flag&BFCHG) != 0)                /* "*" if changed. */
01776         vtputc('*');
01777     else
01778         vtputc('-');
01779 
01780     n  = 2;
01781     cp = " MicroEMACS -- ";
01782 
01783     while ((c = *cp++) != 0)
01784         {
01785         vtputc(c);
01786         ++n;
01787         }
01788 
01789     cp = &bp->b_bname[0];
01790 
01791     while ((c = *cp++) != 0)
01792         {
01793         vtputc(c);
01794         ++n;
01795         }
01796 
01797     vtputc(' ');
01798     ++n;
01799 
01800     if (bp->b_fname[0] != 0)            /* File name. */
01801         {
01802         cp = "-- File: ";
01803 
01804         while ((c = *cp++) != 0)
01805             {
01806             vtputc(c);
01807             ++n;
01808             }
01809 
01810         cp = &bp->b_fname[0];
01811 
01812         while ((c = *cp++) != 0)
01813             {
01814             vtputc(c);
01815             ++n;
01816             }
01817 
01818         vtputc(' ');
01819         ++n;
01820         }
01821 
01822 #if WFDEBUG
01823     vtputc('-');
01824     vtputc((wp->w_flag&WFMODE)!=0  ? 'M' : '-');
01825     vtputc((wp->w_flag&WFHARD)!=0  ? 'H' : '-');
01826     vtputc((wp->w_flag&WFEDIT)!=0  ? 'E' : '-');
01827     vtputc((wp->w_flag&WFMOVE)!=0  ? 'V' : '-');
01828     vtputc((wp->w_flag&WFFORCE)!=0 ? 'F' : '-');
01829     n += 6;
01830 #endif
01831 
01832     while (n < term.t_ncol)             /* Pad to full width. */
01833         {
01834         vtputc('-');
01835         ++n;
01836         }
01837 }
01838 
01839 /*
01840  * Send a command to the terminal to move the hardware cursor to row "row"
01841  * and column "col". The row and column arguments are origin 0. Optimize out
01842  * random calls. Update "ttrow" and "ttcol".
01843  */
01844 globle void movecursor(
01845 int row,
01846 int col)
01847     {
01848     if (row!=ttrow || col!=ttcol)
01849         {
01850         ttrow = row;
01851         ttcol = col;
01852         (*term.t_move)(row, col);
01853         }
01854     }
01855 
01856 /*
01857  * Erase the message line. This is a special routine because the message line
01858  * is not considered to be part of the virtual screen. It always works
01859  * immediately; the terminal buffer is flushed via a call to the flusher.
01860  */
01861 globle void mlerase()
01862     {
01863     movecursor(term.t_nrow, 0);
01864     (*term.t_eeol)();
01865     (*term.t_flush)();
01866     mpresf = FALSE;
01867     }
01868 
01869 /*
01870  * Ask a yes or no question in the message line. Return either TRUE, FALSE, or
01871  * ABORT. The ABORT status is returned if the user bumps out of the question
01872  * with a ^G. Used any time a confirmation is required.
01873  */
01874 globle int mlyesno(
01875     void *theEnv,
01876     char *prompt)
01877     {
01878     register int s;
01879     char buf[64];
01880 
01881     for (;;)
01882         {
01883         genstrcpy(buf, prompt);
01884         genstrcat(buf, " [y/n]? ");
01885         s = mlreply(theEnv,buf, buf, sizeof(buf));
01886 
01887         if (s == ABORT)
01888             return (ABORT);
01889 
01890         if (s != FALSE)
01891             {
01892             if (buf[0]=='y' || buf[0]=='Y')
01893                 return (TRUE);
01894 
01895             if (buf[0]=='n' || buf[0]=='N')
01896                 return (FALSE);
01897             }
01898         }
01899     }
01900 
01901 /*
01902  * Write a prompt into the message line, then read back a response. Keep
01903  * track of the physical position of the cursor. If we are in a keyboard
01904  * macro throw the prompt away, and return the remembered response. This
01905  * lets macros run at full speed. The reply is always terminated by a
01906  * carriage return. Handle erase, kill, and abort keys.
01907  */
01908 globle int mlreply(
01909    void *theEnv,
01910     char *prompt,
01911     char *buf,
01912     int nbuf)
01913     {
01914     register int cpos;
01915     register int i;
01916     register int c;
01917 
01918     cpos = 0;
01919 
01920     if (kbdmop != NULL)
01921         {
01922         while ((c = *kbdmop++) != '\0')
01923             buf[cpos++] = (char) c;
01924 
01925         buf[cpos] = 0;
01926 
01927         if (buf[0] == 0)
01928             return (FALSE);
01929 
01930         return (TRUE);
01931         }
01932 
01933     mlwrite(prompt);
01934 
01935     for (;;)
01936         {
01937         c = (*term.t_getchar)();
01938 
01939         switch (c)
01940             {
01941             case 0x0D:                  /* Return, end of line */
01942                 buf[cpos++] = 0;
01943 
01944                 if (kbdmip != NULL)
01945                     {
01946                     if (kbdmip+cpos > &kbdm[NKBDM-3])
01947                         {
01948                         ctrlg(theEnv,FALSE, 0);
01949                         (*term.t_flush)();
01950                         return (ABORT);
01951                         }
01952 
01953                     for (i=0; i<cpos; ++i)
01954                         *kbdmip++ = buf[i];
01955                     }
01956 
01957                 (*term.t_putchar)('\r');
01958                 ttcol = 0;
01959                 (*term.t_flush)();
01960 
01961                 if (buf[0] == 0)
01962                     return (FALSE);
01963 
01964                 return (TRUE);
01965 
01966             case 0x07:                  /* Bell, abort */
01967                 (*term.t_putchar)('^');
01968                 (*term.t_putchar)('G');
01969                 ttcol += 2;
01970                 ctrlg(theEnv,FALSE, 0);
01971                 (*term.t_flush)();
01972                 return (ABORT);
01973 
01974             case 0x7F:                  /* Rubout, erase */
01975             case 0x08:                  /* Backspace, erase */
01976                 if (cpos != 0)
01977                     {
01978                     (*term.t_putchar)('\b');
01979                     (*term.t_putchar)(' ');
01980                     (*term.t_putchar)('\b');
01981                     --ttcol;
01982 
01983                     if (buf[--cpos] < 0x20)
01984                         {
01985                         (*term.t_putchar)('\b');
01986                         (*term.t_putchar)(' ');
01987                         (*term.t_putchar)('\b');
01988                         --ttcol;
01989                         }
01990 
01991                     (*term.t_flush)();
01992                     }
01993 
01994                 break;
01995 
01996             case 0x15:                  /* C-U, kill */
01997                 while (cpos != 0)
01998                     {
01999                     (*term.t_putchar)('\b');
02000                     (*term.t_putchar)(' ');
02001                     (*term.t_putchar)('\b');
02002                     --ttcol;
02003 
02004                     if (buf[--cpos] < 0x20)
02005                         {
02006                         (*term.t_putchar)('\b');
02007                         (*term.t_putchar)(' ');
02008                         (*term.t_putchar)('\b');
02009                         --ttcol;
02010                         }
02011                     }
02012 
02013                 (*term.t_flush)();
02014                 break;
02015 
02016             default:
02017                 if (cpos < nbuf-1)
02018                     {
02019                     buf[cpos++] = (char) c;
02020 
02021                     if (c < ' ')
02022                         {
02023                         (*term.t_putchar)('^');
02024                         ++ttcol;
02025                         c ^= 0x40;
02026                         }
02027 
02028                     (*term.t_putchar)(c);
02029                     ++ttcol;
02030                     (*term.t_flush)();
02031                     }
02032             }
02033         }
02034     }
02035 
02036 /*
02037  * Write a message into the message line. Keep track of the physical cursor
02038  * position. A small class of printf like format items is handled. Assumes the
02039  * stack grows down; this assumption is made by the "++" in the argument scan
02040  * loop. Set the "message line" flag TRUE.
02041  */
02042 
02043 globle void mlwrite(char *fmt,...)
02044     {
02045     register int c;
02046     va_list ap;
02047 
02048     movecursor(term.t_nrow, 0);
02049     va_start(ap,fmt);
02050     while ((c = *fmt++) != 0) {
02051         if (c != '%') {
02052             (*term.t_putchar)(c);
02053             ++ttcol;
02054             }
02055         else
02056             {
02057             c = *fmt++;
02058             switch (c) {
02059                 case 'd':
02060                     mlputi(va_arg(ap,int), 10);
02061                     break;
02062 
02063                 case 'o':
02064                     mlputi(va_arg(ap,int),  8);
02065                     break;
02066 
02067                 case 'x':
02068                     mlputi(va_arg(ap,int), 16);
02069                     break;
02070 
02071                 case 'D':
02072                     mlputli(va_arg(ap,long), 10);
02073                     break;
02074 
02075                 case 's':
02076                     mlputs(va_arg(ap,char *));
02077                     break;
02078 
02079                 default:
02080                     (*term.t_putchar)(c);
02081                     ++ttcol;
02082                 }
02083             }
02084         }
02085     va_end(ap);
02086     (*term.t_eeol)();
02087     (*term.t_flush)();
02088     mpresf = TRUE;
02089     }
02090 
02091 /*
02092  * Write out a string. Update the physical cursor position. This assumes that
02093  * the characters in the string all have width "1"; if this is not the case
02094  * things will get screwed up a little.
02095  */
02096 globle void mlputs(
02097     char *s)
02098     {
02099     register int c;
02100 
02101     while ((c = *s++) != 0)
02102         {
02103         (*term.t_putchar)(c);
02104         ++ttcol;
02105         }
02106     }
02107 
02108 /*
02109  * Write out an integer, in the specified radix. Update the physical cursor
02110  * position. This will not handle any negative numbers; maybe it should.
02111  */
02112 globle void mlputi(
02113 int i,
02114 int r)
02115     {
02116     register int q;
02117     static char hexdigits[] = "0123456789ABCDEF";
02118 
02119     if (i < 0)
02120         {
02121         i = -i;
02122         (*term.t_putchar)('-');
02123         }
02124 
02125     q = i/r;
02126 
02127     if (q != 0)
02128         mlputi(q, r);
02129 
02130     (*term.t_putchar)(hexdigits[i%r]);
02131     ++ttcol;
02132     }
02133 
02134 /*
02135  * do the same except as a long integer.
02136  */
02137 globle void mlputli(
02138     long l,
02139     int r)
02140     {
02141     register long q;
02142 
02143     if (l < 0)
02144         {
02145         l = -l;
02146         (*term.t_putchar)('-');
02147         }
02148 
02149     q = l/r;
02150 
02151     if (q != 0)
02152         mlputli(q, r);
02153 
02154     (*term.t_putchar)((int)(l%r)+'0');
02155     ++ttcol;
02156     }
02157 
02158 
02159 globle void kill_video_buffers(
02160   void *theEnv)
02161   {
02162     int i;
02163 
02164     for (i = 0; i < term.t_nrow; ++i) {
02165         genfree(theEnv,(void *) vscreen[i],(unsigned) (sizeof(VIDEO)+term.t_ncol));
02166         genfree(theEnv,(void *) pscreen[i],(unsigned) (sizeof(VIDEO)+term.t_ncol));
02167         }
02168 
02169     genfree(theEnv,(void *) vscreen, (unsigned) (term.t_nrow*sizeof(VIDEO *)));
02170     genfree(theEnv,(void *) pscreen, (unsigned) (term.t_nrow*sizeof(VIDEO *)));
02171    }
02172 
02173 static void int_to_ascii(
02174 char   buf[],
02175 int    width,
02176 int    num)
02177 {
02178         buf[width] = 0;                         /* End of string.       */
02179         while (num >= 10) {                     /* Conditional digits.  */
02180                 buf[--width] = (char) (num%10) + '0';
02181                 num /= 10;
02182         }
02183         buf[--width] = (char) num + '0';        /* Always 1 digit.      */
02184         while (width != 0)                      /* Pad with blanks.     */
02185                 buf[--width] = ' ';
02186 }
